Simply the best Idle Game I have ever played.

It combines RuneScape levelling, with endless QoL features to make the Idle game aspect work alongside it really well. The balance of interaction and idling in this game is fantastic, and makes progression feel more personal knowing theres no wrong path to take in your Bloobs Adventure.
One of the neat features included is called [b]Banked Time[/b], saving any time away from the game, weather closed or AFK, and being able to use that time as a 2x or 3x Speed boost that can be toggled on to help catch up on lost time.

The art style, sound design and overall pacing of the game is charming and makes the whole world of your Bloobs feel alive and engaged with the details you come across. 

Combat in Bloobs will reward you for being prepared long term, along with combining other skills to improve your stats. Everything feels connected amongst your Bloobs Idle World and you will find many skills compliment each other to help levelling faster. Some skills will feel slow to begin with but the snowball effect eventually takes over and feels very satisfying when you plan everything out perfectly to get that one skill to that certain level.

Finally the Dev is just a straight up fantastic bloke, constantly working on the game to bring out updates and fixes that any Bloobs come across, always open to ideas and listening for feedback. A one man army indeed. 
With there being a new skill coming out very soon, along with the huge amount of content already available, you should definitely give this one a go.

- Extraordinarily low price for what already feels like a full-featured RS experience
- Freakishly rapid updates with community feedback having a big impact 
- The idle chillax experience of Melvor without staring at grey menus - the overworld here is classic fantasy comfiness and watching your Bloob perform backbreaking labour is just a nice thing to have off on the side
- 100% stress free: no losing items when you die, just efficiency
- Unique prestige system with 10 levels, I wouldn't call it the most elegant or complex system but its novel for this style of game and its very addicting to chase them
- Content for skills exceeds even level 120 and apparently content up to 1000 is planned (!)

And one thing which might be a positive or negative depending on what experience you want:
- The interactivity between skills is definitely on the lower end compared to the other games here, that can just be temporary or a design decision I'm not sure but for me I quite like it. It makes progression feel very fun no matter what I'm doing instead of the stress that something like Melvor can induce where I'm looking at one thing I want to do but then taking 10 steps back to stack as many bonuses as possible first. YMMV.

[h1]Idle Grindy Crafty Fun![/h1]


Okay, I'm just gonna warn you right away:  You will spend thousands and [b][i]THOUSANDS[/i][/b] of hours in this game.

Seriously.

I'm posting at a thousand hours in, and I've barely made a dent in the content the dev already has in (content up to level 200), and he plans on extending content up to freaking level 1000!

[i]Dwarf Fortress[/i] fans can relate.  This game, [i]Bloob's Adventure Idle,[/i] is like if Tarn Adams of DF fame decided to create an idle grindy crafty game.  Dev starts game with huge to-do list to start and keeps thinking of stuff to throw in, releases game soon after it's in a playable state, eternal early access.


You are Bloob, a creature resembling a [i]Dragon Quest[/i] slime, who woke up one day with very little memory of who or what you are, but with an intense drive to go train up in various skills.  Despite the fact that you are not exactly humanoid, these skills are the usual RPG ones and take standard human equipment.  Your slimeball form can craft and shoot arrows, mine and forge, and wear standard human armor.


There are two play modes to choose, Normal and Turbo, and you can't switch once you start your game.  Turbo runs the game at 10x speed.  The mere fact that the game has this option should tell you just what you are in for.


You start in or near a small town with a shop and a few basic crafting stations stashed in various buildings.

The world map is a tad confusing at first, as if the dev just kept throwing in new features, and some resource/enemy locations are not all that intuitive.  At certain zoom levels, it's a bit hard to tell what's what, but tooltips help.

Fortunately, there are several auto-move features built in.  A list of what all you can do in most skills is available with just a click or two, and you can click on that item in the skill UI to automatically go to it.  Some skills have handy shortcut buttons to take you to its crafting station.  There are a couple handy teleport buttons around the small world map in the upper right corner, and some more teleport spells available once you start crafting runes.


The skills you can do are all interconnected to one degree or another.  There's the basic fighting skills of melee, magic, and ranged.  Each has weapons that can be crafted from harvested materials.  Magic also requires runic slates that must be crafted and then imbued at an altar with a specific rune.  Each style has its own armor that gives penalties for the other two styles.

Combat damage is healed with food, which can be cooked.  Right now, the food recipes are just simply cooked meat or fish.  However, the dev is said to be working on a farming skill that will allow you to cook vegetarian meals.

Food right now can be stolen from stalls or harvested from animals.  Besides killing animals for standard combat xp, food animals can be fished up or tracked and trapped.

Herbology creates potions for various buffs.  Herbs are foraged.  Even the vials have to be crafted from glass made from sand from mined sandstone, and then filled with well water in another crafting move.

Then there are the several support skills.  Wood can be cut for weapons and used to make fires.  You can craft urns and sacrifice the bones of your fallen enemies for Devotion points that can be used for temporary buffs.

Beastmastery is about killing instead of taming, and is based on bounties for kill quests.  Points earned here can be redeemed at the Beastmaster for resource packs, extra inventory slots, and some upgrades.


You earn XP in each skill as you use them.  Reaching level 100 in a skill allows you to prestige it.  This sends you back to the beginning, but with a nice boost to XP earning.  Prestiging craft skills allows for a chance at an instant craft.  Magic and Range combat prestige gives a chance at a free cast/shot.


One of the more interesting skills to prestige is Dexterity.  This isn't a dodge stat.  It's simply run speed.  Leveling up Dexterity increases your speed.

There's not yet an offline task XP earning mechanic, so instead, you gain hours spent offline.  These hours are put into a bank for you to spend at double time and 3x speeds.

This bank begins at an already generous 36 hours.  At 3x speed, you can spend twelve hours at that speed.  At default speeds, you'll be wanted to speed things up a bit, so this bank comes in quite handy.

Prestiging Dexterity adds to base run speed and increases the bank for the hours you get to spend at extra speed.


The game runs well in the background.  However, early on, and after prestiging a skill, you'll have to babysit the game.  Inventory slots have infinite stacks, so running out of room for a product isn't a problem so long as you have a slot free.  But you'll have a limited number of slots at first and will need to either sell some items or offload them into a bank (more like a large vault).

Your bank/vault slots are limited in number but also infinite in stacks.  You buy more slots with the gold you earn, mostly from selling loot and crafted items.

Another reason to babysit the game is to catch when you run out of ammo or imbued slates or crafting materials.  Or, you know, die.  Fortunately, you instantly respawn in the central town and have infinite lives.

If you're AFK for a while, the game recently added a feature that adds time spent not earning XP back into the banked hours for extra speed.  So you don't have to be too obsessive about checking the game.


This is a cool, fun game, and extremely cheap compared to the many hours you might put into it.  It's best played in long spurts, like while you're working on something.  Levels are earned fairly quickly, especially at 3x speed or in Turbo mode.

But you can also chip away at it a few minutes at a time.  Even the combat skills that require you to make ammo, Range and Magic, don't feel too much of a chore to level up, especially since you're leveling up the crafting skills as you make more ammo.

If you aren't afraid of committing to a game for the next decade of your life, come play as Bloob!

Bloob's does an absolutely excellent job of giving the same grind-induced-endorphins as RuneScape with one key change - particularly key if you value your time. The distinct lack of punishment for not having the game running, or not catching something right as the smithing queue ends.

The game has 2 primary layer to prevent the "OMG IM MISSING EXP" feeling that you get from RuneScape. 

The first is a starting "AFK" timer of 36 hours (this can be further increased to 96 hours with game play - NOT pay to win.) This timer starts after 5 minutes of inactivity, or when the game is closed. This time can be redeemed at 100% via a "double the speed" mechanic.

The second is, after prestiging most skills once, an "auto-[skill]" system. This allows you to fully afk a skill when time just doesn't allow more intricate game play.

Highly recommend for anyone craving RuneScape like gameplay, without the time commitments.

[h1]Idle Grindy Crafty Fun![/h1]


Okay, I'm just gonna warn you right away:  You will spend thousands and [b][i]THOUSANDS[/i][/b] of hours in this game.

Seriously.

I'm posting at a thousand hours in, and I've barely made a dent in the content the dev already has in (content up to level 200), and he plans on extending content up to freaking level 1000!

[i]Dwarf Fortress[/i] fans can relate.  This game, [i]Bloob's Adventure Idle,[/i] is like if Tarn Adams of DF fame decided to create an idle grindy crafty game.  Dev starts game with huge to-do list to start and keeps thinking of stuff to throw in, releases game soon after it's in a playable state, eternal early access.


You are Bloob, a creature resembling a [i]Dragon Quest[/i] slime, who woke up one day with very little memory of who or what you are, but with an intense drive to go train up in various skills.  Despite the fact that you are not exactly humanoid, these skills are the usual RPG ones and take standard human equipment.  Your slimeball form can craft and shoot arrows, mine and forge, and wear standard human armor.


There are two play modes to choose, Normal and Turbo, and you can't switch once you start your game.  Turbo runs the game at 10x speed.  The mere fact that the game has this option should tell you just what you are in for.


You start in or near a small town with a shop and a few basic crafting stations stashed in various buildings.

The world map is a tad confusing at first, as if the dev just kept throwing in new features, and some resource/enemy locations are not all that intuitive.  At certain zoom levels, it's a bit hard to tell what's what, but tooltips help.

Fortunately, there are several auto-move features built in.  A list of what all you can do in most skills is available with just a click or two, and you can click on that item in the skill UI to automatically go to it.  Some skills have handy shortcut buttons to take you to its crafting station.  There are a couple handy teleport buttons around the small world map in the upper right corner, and some more teleport spells available once you start crafting runes.


The skills you can do are all interconnected to one degree or another.  There's the basic fighting skills of melee, magic, and ranged.  Each has weapons that can be crafted from harvested materials.  Magic also requires runic slates that must be crafted and then imbued at an altar with a specific rune.  Each style has its own armor that gives penalties for the other two styles.

Combat damage is healed with food, which can be cooked.  Right now, the food recipes are just simply cooked meat or fish.  However, the dev is said to be working on a farming skill that will allow you to cook vegetarian meals.

Food right now can be stolen from stalls or harvested from animals.  Besides killing animals for standard combat xp, food animals can be fished up or tracked and trapped.

Herbology creates potions for various buffs.  Herbs are foraged.  Even the vials have to be crafted from glass made from sand from mined sandstone, and then filled with well water in another crafting move.

Then there are the several support skills.  Wood can be cut for weapons and used to make fires.  You can craft urns and sacrifice the bones of your fallen enemies for Devotion points that can be used for temporary buffs.

Beastmastery is about killing instead of taming, and is based on bounties for kill quests.  Points earned here can be redeemed at the Beastmaster for resource packs, extra inventory slots, and some upgrades.


You earn XP in each skill as you use them.  Reaching level 100 in a skill allows you to prestige it.  This sends you back to the beginning, but with a nice boost to XP earning.  Prestiging craft skills allows for a chance at an instant craft.  Magic and Range combat prestige gives a chance at a free cast/shot.


One of the more interesting skills to prestige is Dexterity.  This isn't a dodge stat.  It's simply run speed.  Leveling up Dexterity increases your speed.

There's not yet an offline task XP earning mechanic, so instead, you gain hours spent offline.  These hours are put into a bank for you to spend at double time and 3x speeds.

This bank begins at an already generous 36 hours.  At 3x speed, you can spend twelve hours at that speed.  At default speeds, you'll be wanted to speed things up a bit, so this bank comes in quite handy.

Prestiging Dexterity adds to base run speed and increases the bank for the hours you get to spend at extra speed.


The game runs well in the background.  However, early on, and after prestiging a skill, you'll have to babysit the game.  Inventory slots have infinite stacks, so running out of room for a product isn't a problem so long as you have a slot free.  But you'll have a limited number of slots at first and will need to either sell some items or offload them into a bank (more like a large vault).

Your bank/vault slots are limited in number but also infinite in stacks.  You buy more slots with the gold you earn, mostly from selling loot and crafted items.

Another reason to babysit the game is to catch when you run out of ammo or imbued slates or crafting materials.  Or, you know, die.  Fortunately, you instantly respawn in the central town and have infinite lives.

If you're AFK for a while, the game recently added a feature that adds time spent not earning XP back into the banked hours for extra speed.  So you don't have to be too obsessive about checking the game.


This is a cool, fun game, and extremely cheap compared to the many hours you might put into it.  It's best played in long spurts, like while you're working on something.  Levels are earned fairly quickly, especially at 3x speed or in Turbo mode.

But you can also chip away at it a few minutes at a time.  Even the combat skills that require you to make ammo, Range and Magic, don't feel too much of a chore to level up, especially since you're leveling up the crafting skills as you make more ammo.

If you aren't afraid of committing to a game for the next decade of your life, come play as Bloob!

TL;DR Give it a shot, it's free! It's a delightful idle game, but definitely slow to progress and with no* offline progression.

*- OK let's start with that caveat. To be technical, the big innovation for Bloobs Adventure Idle is that all of your progression is almost sort of offline-gated: Time spent offline or fully AFK (IE, doing nothing) produces Banked Time. You can spend this ~1:1 to double the game's tickrate, or ~3:1 to triple it. So for 16 hours spent offline, you can spend 8 hours online going much faster. This is neat! It enforces a cap to offline 'gains', and it's got a good cadence. The downside is that the multipliers, 2x and 3x, are WAY too slow. This game is glacial to the point of self-parody on 1x, and even at 3x it's kinda grindy.

OK on with the bulk of the actual review: Bloobs is great! It's Runescape minus all of the worst parts but plus a few new worst parts (looking at you, Beastmastery balancing and Trapping progression) in an act of equivalent exchange. The art is cute, the developer is constantly on the ball and keeping things updated, and the diversity of skills is really fun to mess around with. At time of writing the first new skill since I started playing just got added today, Homesteading, a sort of combo player housing / Farming deal, and it's very slick.

My advice if you're gonna try the game? Don't bother with non-melee combat for anything progression related, just come back and grind Magic and Ranged later. Do Beastmastery as often as possible when you are fighting for stuff, and ideally get Auto Beastmaster early and then grind the 5 point missions: Anything seemingly higher-value is actually much lower value due to higher kill requirements and bad KPM, even with improved gear.

Regardless, it's free and absolutely worth trying out.
